YAML is a text format, you can read it in with e.g. unparsed-text('foo.yaml'), you can process it with all text processing features you have in XSLT 3 (i.e. analyze-string, tokenize, grouping, matching) to transform it to maps/arrays or XML and then process that further. Whether it is in the end easier to have someone write YAML to have a transpiler to to create XSLT instead of having people write XSLT directly (e.g. <xsl:template match="ABC"/> seems to be what your -element: ABC action: removeElement: true amounts to) I doubt. It all depends on the skill sets of people involved.

You can iterate over a str2.toCharArray, and utilize a few local variables to determine if there are occurrences of str1 within the array. Would this not be O(n)?

The input data that makes this an interesting problem is one with overlap. So, not abc. Try doing this exercise for inputs: str1: ana str2: banananas. The correct answer is presumably [1, 3, 5]. A simple forward search will fail and answer [1, 5]. Yes, this can be done in O(N). Keep track of how 'far' into the needle string you are, once you get to the end - you found an index. The trick is in how you 'reset' the count when your algorithm concludes (either found a match, or knows there is no match). You can't just reset that to 0; you might be halfway to a new match already.
Yes, KMP is a good choice for this problem
Anyway, your conclusion that indexOf is O(N) time complexity is incorrect ... depending on which overload of indexOf you use and what N is. And you shouldn't be using substring at all.
A performance function for problem actually has three variables: A = the number of occurrences, B = length of str1, C = length of str2.  Which of these is your N?

As I mentioned, to get an instance if Client you need to walk through the chain of fields/methods starting from a static context. Or you can use JVM TI to scan the entire heap for all instances of Client class. See this answer for details.

This Client is a public interface Client extends OAuthApi. Which contains a method int getIndex().

You're probably mixing up things. No matter if you use FindClass or GetLoadedClasses, regardless of the ClassLoader used, in the end you will get an instance of java.lang.Class, not an instance the class you're looking for. To get an instance of a class, you need to access it through a chain of references from some root object, e.g., through static fields. Alternatively, you may use IterateThroughHeap JVM TI function to find all instances of a given class.

Why do you want your caching (infrastructure) components and beans to be request scoped? Are you expecting the cache to be cleared (i.e. re-created) after each request? What is your UC? Setting the CacheManageter bean to request scope will not accomplish that, not unless the CacheManager provider implementation also implemented Spring's lifecycle interfaces. This would be a very expensive operation (recreating caches on each request) depending on the caching provider in use and not even practical in a distributed context using a client/server caching topology as is often the case.

If you generate your project via start.spring.io, you will see that you don't need all those versions specified. Spring Boot handles this automatically to select compatible versions.

If you're including versions of Spring dependencies, you're usually clobbering the management and going to cause problems. In particular, you are pulling in 5.0.0 and 5.5.0; eliminate all of these versions and let Boot do its job.

@DmitryBrant After reading again, my apologies, I tend to agree with your statement. Not so much though with your first comment that got an awful lot of upvotes. There can be good reasons for rounding in only one direction, but normally not this way.

@jerry In that case, the question is extremely confusingly phrased and should be rewritten, with perhaps a brief mention of OP's use case for this rounding scheme. Rounding up to 1 decimal place would mean that 0.000001 would become 0.1. It's not at all clear from the question that this is what OP wants.

@DmitryBrant, Andy Turner, Felipe Andrade, I'm feeling somewhat sorry for Noelia here being repeatedly reprimanded with such ill-informed comments.   For anyone visiting this page: What Noelia is asking for is called "rounding up", it is not the same as "ceiling" (negative numbers!), whether it is mathematically correct or not is a matter of definition, and most languages I know, including Kotlin and Java, support this rounding mode. It does not take much imagination to think of applications in finance (e.g. a simple piggy-bank saving plan offered by some banks) or in automation.

As a general rule, unless you really know what you're doing, avoid importing anything from the java.awt.* or java.swing.* packages when creating a JavaFX application. All code related to the JavaFX standard library is in packages starting with javafx.*.

"There is no setContent method when I try to repeat the example" – I think this was the piece of information we were missing. As you can see in the documentation, that method does indeed exist and has existed since JavaFX 2.0 (which is approximately 10 major versions older than the version you're using). My guess is you erroneously imported java.awt.ScrollPane. But javafx.scene.control.ScrollPane is the class you want to import.

it is specified in the Java Language Specification 8.4.8. Inheritance, Overriding, and Hiding: "A class C inherits from its direct superclass type D all concrete methods m (both static and instance) for which all of the following are true: • m is a member of D. • m is public, protected, or declared with package access in the same package as C. • No method declared in C has a signature that is a subsignature (§8.4.2) of the signature of m as a member of D. ... "

When calling .split(" "), it makes a further call to split(String regex, int limit) where limit = 0 (which means it's unbound). The doc further states If the expression does not match any part of the input then the resulting array has just one element, namely this string and A zero-width match at the beginning however never produces such empty leading substring and If the limit is zero then the pattern will be applied as many times as possible, the array can have any length, and trailing empty strings will be discarded.

Ways regex can break when "just appending a few zeroes to a number" if you don't fully control possible inputs: the string expected to be a number contains non-digits (e.g. . or E) - what do you do? @MariuszS I read that as an attempt to dismiss legitimate use cases instead of admiting the tool has limitations that cannot be (easily) removed, and without providing any reasoned justification. BTW, here is such a discussion for the opposite viewpoint, with references.

@Rogério Thanks for explanation. github.com/mockito/mockito/wiki/FAQ Can I mock static methods? No. Mockito prefers object orientation and dependency injection over static, procedural code that is hard to understand & change. There is some design behind this limitation too :)

@MariuszS It isn't by design that Mockito (or EasyMock, or jMock) does not support mocking static methods, but by accident. This limitation (along with no support for mocking final classes/methods, or new-ed objects) is a natural (but unintended) consequence of the approach employed to implement mocking, where new classes are dynamically created that implement/extend the type to be mocked; other mocking libraries use other approaches which avoid these limitations. This happened in the .NET world as well.

A painting method is for painting only. Don't have Timer logic in the painting method. Painting is done by using the Graphics object passed to the paintComponent() method of a JPanel. See: stackoverflow.com/a/54028681/131872 for an example of using a Swing Timer for animation.

Use a Swing Timer instead of java.util.Timer. Don't start timer in paint - in fact, don't override paint and don't paint directly to the frame, use a JPanel instead - see Performing Custom Painting and How to Use Swing Timers - for example

Supporting a single client at a time isn't the same thing as only supporting one message per connection. If you need message sequencing, you must send them all over the same connection. If the server won't support multiple clients at a time, don't execute multiple clients at the same time, or let the subsequent ones just wait until the prior one closes its connection. This will happen automatically up to the backlog limit. Are you sure you are implementing the application protocol correctly? TCP doesn't lose data.

expression = expression.replace(character, ' '); will replace all character occurances. So "11+".replace('1',' ') will become " +". To replace first occurrence of that character you may want to use replaceFirst. Since it uses regex, you want to generate regex which represents that character (in case such character is regex metacharacter like +). To do that you can use Pattern.quote but it expects String. So you also need to convert your character to String first. Final version could look like expression = expression.replaceFirst(Pattern.quote(""+character), "");.

That said, a more typical way to do this is storing a Handler reference in the Activity (e.g. through Handler handler = new Handler(Looper.getMainLooper())) and then posting runnables to it, like with handler.post(Runnable), or postDelayed etc. Then the code you need to run is just written in the run method. And you don't even need a Handler for this - Views implicitly have their own reference to one, so you can just call tv.post(Runnable) to run a thing on the UI thread
@Marwan: public class MyHandler extends Handler { MainActivity mainActivity; public MyHandler(MainActivity mainactivity) { this.mainActivity = activity; }

@Marwan you need to inject your dependencies into the MyHandler class - basically, whatever objects it needs to use, you pass them in rather than constructing them inside MyHandler. You could either do it as a constructor parameter, or as a parameter on a function you're calling (e.g. you could write one that calls sendEmptyMessage internally). That way you can just pass in the Activity or whatever (in this case you should probably be passing in the TextView since that's specifically the thing you're interacting with). You'll see this pattern a lot with passing a Context parameter

Regarding the encoding: the hex encoding of the data before encryption is actually unnecessary and only increases the amount of data to be encrypted. Encryption algorithms operate on bytes, so the binary data itself should be encrypted (and not its hex encoding). Unless the Java/Python code is fixed, this should be changed.

At first glance I don't see any problems, but this should be verified by tests. My recommendation: get the decryption code, write it yourself (language doesn't matter) or use online tools (most are unreliable, a relatively good one that also supports RSA/OAEP/SHA256 is CyberChef), and perform the necessary tests: Create an RSA test key pair, generate a ciphertext with both codes and decrypt both. But as has already been explained, it's simply not possible to "pause/resume md5 and sha256 hash object from standard "hashlib" module". The state data needed to make it possible is not accessible in any way via the Python hashlib and its hash objects. However, a new, functionally-equivalent, implementation of hashlib could allow such pausing and resuming, since the struct SHAstate_st aka SHA_CTX is accessible to C programs that use OpenSSL. See <openssl/sha.h> (on my system that header is in /usr/include).

A hash algorithm is simply something that takes an object and returns an integer. Ideally, every unique object would result in a different integer. Though that's not always possible. Now, in Java's HashMap, the hash is gotten by calling the hashCode() method on the key. Naively, the index would be computed by doing something like int index = key.hashCode() % array.length. Though HashMap, if I'm not mistaken, does some more advanced things to make the implementation better somehow.

@Slaw Ok, so that's more what I'm asking for, but really I'm asking how the "hash" algorithm that I did not create is able to produce the index of the key that I'm looking for when my input is NOT the index but the value at the index which is not known yet. But I will research hash tables. Thank you for your explanation.

I recommend you research hash tables. What I'm saying will make much more sense if you understand how the implementation works. But again, the hash is computed from the key, and the index is computed from the hash. You are passing the key to the containsKey method as an argument. So, it does know which index to search in the array. That's why I keep bringing up that accessing an array is O(1) time. You only ever look at one location; you don't search the entire array. That's different from an ArrayList, which does search the array linearly.

@Slaw HashMap.containsKey() and ArrayList.contains() are used when you do not know if the data structure contains an element, therefore you do not know the index or if it even exists, therefore you must search the data structure. I am asking about a search operation, not an access operation.
start and end are not great names. I would use something like indexOfNextLeadingCharacterToCheck and indexOfNextTrailingCharacterToCheck
The start index goes 0, 1, 2, etc. The end index goes N, N - 1, N - 2, etc. When they meet in the middle (start > end) both sides of the palindrome have been verified and the method returns true.

As explained, the hash of the key is used to compute the index of the array to access. Accessing an array at a specific index is O(1). So, yes, you are implicitly asking about an access operation. Research hash tables and this will start to make more sense to you.

@Slaw "if you know the index you want to look at then accessing the array is O(1)" I am asking about a search operation for a map and a list, more specifically a has map and an array list, I am not asking about an access operation.

The HashMap implementation, specifically, uses a hash table internally. The nature of a hash table means a lookup can happen in O(1) time, because all that matters is whether the bucket the key's hash falls into contains the key (though it gets a little more complicated when dealing with hash collisions). The "table" is an array, and if you know the index you want to look at then accessing the array is O(1). An ArrayList does not use a hash table. It just uses an array "as is". Therefore, it has to search the entire array linearly to see if it contains the element, which is an O(n) task.

Strings are immutable in Java. You can reassign different Strings to String variables, but each String object itself can never be changed. The replace method of String does not change the String, because Strings cannot be changed. The method creates a new String value and returns it. It’s up to you to make use of that returned value.

First fix your for loops so you won't get out of bounds errors. The outer loop, with z, should be z < test.length. The inner loop, with i, should be i< test[z].length()-1 since you are accessing the character to the right of the current position. Then you need to assign the return value of String.replace() back to your original array position with test[z] = test[z].replace(test[z].charAt(i+1), c);. But the bigger problem is that replace is going to change ALL OCCURRENCES of that char to the replacement value. If you only want to replace that position then use a different approach.
without digging deeper in the code, I can already see 2 huge problems: outer loop should be for(int z=0; z<test.length; z++) and the inner loop should be for(int i=0; i<test[z].length() - 1; i++)

I don't think your interpretation is correct. Let's say you set the refresh time to 1 minute and the expire time to 2 minutes. If you make a request after the 1 minute mark and before the 2 minute mark, you should get back the existing (stale) value immediately while it starts refreshing the value in the background (and stale values will be returned until either the refresh completes or the expire time occurs, whichever is first). However, if no requests are issued within 2 minutes of the last time the key was loaded...sure, you'll hit the expire time instead and be hit with a blocking call.

But it's so hard to fix this problem with our computer programs that we're probably going to make a change to the real world, instead.

The problem is that Reactor actually forbids calling block in Schedulers not explicitly marked as compatible with blocking code. I do not find detailed doc about that, but I think that. you have to use either subscribeOn(Schedulers.boundedElastic()) or .share() method on your flux before block call. The difference in behaviour might come from the fact that in one case, block function triggers pipeline in current thread (non reactive scheduler), but in your test, you try to call canDoIt from a reactive stack, so the executing thread comes from a reactive scheduler.

I probably didn't fully understand what you're aiming at. But it sounds like this might be a case where "preparing" the next element should be a separate step. The pattern that is occasionally used here: 1. define a private T next;. 2. Implement hasNext as next!=null. 3. create a method prepareNext that will compute the next element to be returned. 4. In the constructor, do this.next=prepareNext(). 5. In next, do T result=next; this.next=prepareNext(); return result;. If you really want to optimize, avoid using regular expressions for such a simple problem. You could just do this: int i = text.indexOf("purchase"); return i >= 0 && (i == 0 || !Character.isLetter(text.charAt(i))) && (i == text.length() - 8 || !Character.isLetter(text.charAt(i + 8))). It may look longer, but regular expressions do a lot of work under the hood and involve a lot more code than this approach.

If you want to squeeze out the maximum performance with the reference implementation, use Pattern.compile("purchase\\b(?<=\\b.{8})"). Having the literal text at the beginning of the pattern will enable the internal use of the Boyer–Moore algorithm. But avoiding backtracking and reusing the Pattern object are more important.

As @DuncG said, use the right operation, i.e. find() instead of abusing matches() with expensive .* around the pattern. This already avoids backtracking. But you also don’t need capturing groups, so Pattern.compile("\\bpurchase\\b").matcher(text).find() will do. Keep in mind that you can keep and reuse the result of Pattern.compile(…), i.e. instead of storing the pattern string in a static final field, store the Pattern object, so you’re not repeating the work on every invocation.
Should also get same result without ".*" if you use find not matches - Pattern.compile("\\b(purchase)\\b").matcher(text).find() and you can also re-use the Pattern.compile part.

Why are there two .* items in the pattern? The RegEx will have to process the first .* which will match the entire string, then the match for the p in purchase will fail. It will backtrack by one character and the p will fail again, and so on. Perhaps changing to a non-greedy initial part (i.e. to .*?\\b(purchase)\\b.*) would improve matters. But, I repeat, why are the two .* items present.

Java uses a special case (i.e. a subset) of keystore for truststore -- it reads the keystore format and selects the 'trusted' cert(s) in it. For JKS format you can sometimes read cert(s) without the password, but PKCS12 format no. Also unless your PKCS12 was created by Java (e.g. keytool or keystore-explorer) the certs in it won't be considered trusted by the 'sun' provider. I don't use kafka but this asserts you can use PEM (non-keystore) files.

It is labeled "Build and run" in "Edit Configurations", because you can specify if your application should be rebuild before each run - i.e. you can specify some settings that are not "run" settings there as well. Nevertheless, the JRE in "Build and run" is for running the application not for compiling the application. (The application is always compiled with the "Project Structure" -> "SDK" JDK. This is why it is possible to specify a JRE in "Build and run". If that value was used for compiling, it would have to be a JDK, because the javac compiler is not part of a JRE.)

ok thanks @ThomasBehr but to be precise, the "edit configurations.." is not labeled for "run" application but for "build and run" the application. So why to compile with the "project structure" jdk if there is too a "build" jdk ? it is not clear for me.
Maven is a Java application. The second one defines the JRE that is used to run the Maven application.

The first one is the JDK that is used to compile your project. The last one is the one used to run your application. It makes sense to separate those two so you can test how your application runs on different JDKs if you plan to support older JDKs (e.g. project JDK is Java 11 and you need to test on all Java version from 11 to 20). I do not know about the second one, but "Build Tools Maven" -> "Runner" -> "JRE" seems like a strong hint as to its usage.

1) You should not invoke 8doInBackground()* directly. You should invoke the execute() method of the worker. 2) If you change the data in the worker then you should "publish" the results as the data is changed. The process() method of the worker is invoked when data is published and this method executes on the EDT. Read the section from the Swing tutorial on Concurrency for more information. 3) You can check out: stackoverflow.com/a/64196256/131872 for one example of this approach. There may be others.

No, you can't incubator modules are meant to provide a preview/non-final form of a module that's planned to be released in a later JDK. It's like a preview feature in a way. But that means it's only and exclusively available in the JDK that provides it. If it isn't provided in a later JDK then that's likely because plans changed or it's been moved to a "proper" module. There's no way to "add-on" missing incubator modules to existing JDKs. This specific one is now a preview feature in JDK 19.

It's probably not a big deal for simpler, primitive sort of datatypes but the reason I ended up on this page is because I noticed a simple "list documents" query was running slow. That entity has a BLOB column (needs it for file upload/storage) & I suspect it is slow because it is loading the BLOBs into memory even though they're not required for listing the docs.

The "problem" is the side effect that filtering has (you noticed the Warning: filtering may have side effects?). The side effect in this case is that filtering adds the filter string as instance to the memory. You can observe this when you change the filter from equals("test") to contains("tes") before stepping through your code. You will notice that the string "tes" is added to the memory and after that the string "test" is only added twice, the string "test2" only once.

Open the .csv file for input (reading). Create a new file for ouput (writing) with a different name. Use a loop that reads the input file (until empty). For each line read, unless it is one of the lines to be deleted, write it to the output file. After the last line of the input file has been read, which terminates the loop, try this: Close the output file, saving it. Close the input file. Delete the input file. Rename the output file to have the name of the input file.

@DEV No. It is always an error to instantiate @FXML-annotated fields. The annotation explicitly means the field will be initialized by the FXMLLoader.
you are only instanciating this.appController = new AppController();, messageArea must be instanciatet too before calling appController.getMessageArea()

@FXML-annotated fields (such as messageArea) will only be initialized in the controller. They won't be initialized in arbitrary objects just because they happen to be of the same class. Your Client class needs a reference to the actual controller (the one created by the FXMLLoader when you load and display the FXML file). (Or, and probably better, use a MVC approach and get the data from the model, so you don't expose the UI elements outside the presentation layer.)

Never make a lexer rule that collapses all operators into one token type. OP : '+' | '-' | '*' | '/' | '%' | '==' | '!=' | '<' | '<=' | '>' | '>=' | '&&' | '||' | '&' | '|' | '^' | '>>' | '<<';. Just rename it to a parser rule, similar for VARIABLE_MODIFIER. It interferes with working out the rules for the precedence and associativity of operators in the grammar. Best if you read the C grammar and see how it's done.

* and & are operators. Each is two different operators, in fact -- a binary one and a unary one. The same is true of - and +, too, as far as C itself is concerned. The C language spec (see this draft, for example) devotes considerably more grammar productions to expressions than you're trying to get away with. That serves several purposes, but one is certainly to show how to distinguish uses of +, -, &, * as unary operators from uses of the same as binary operators. You should study that.
Have you tried reading ANTLR4 example grammars of similar languages to see how they solved the issue? For exampe the Tiny C grammar.

Your main problem is that you use String for storing the encrypted data. Strings are for ASCII or Unicode data but not for binary data without encoding. Saving binary in a String can modify the data and a modified encrypted data will fail to decrypt. Use proper data types like byte[] or encode the data base64 before using a String for storage.

How is that known at compile time? When that class is compiled there is no hint of what T will be. This will only be known when the class is used, in some other class, eventually compiled some time else - it can even be different types in different uses (the usage of type parameters is exactly not knowing the type at compile time)

At runtime, there is only one MyClass. So there's no way to put "an" annotation on the class becaues T will change. You'd need a mulplicity of annotations to support that, and Java can't do that. There's only one XmlElement annotation at either runtime or compile time, and you do need to work around that.

@MarkoTopolnik Thanks for the explanation. Subjective details aside, it sounds like we basically all agree here.

@mafu My comment was only on Sotirios's reference to the principle that "source code is the best documentation", which makes a distinction between code comments and actual code: it is only the actual code which cannot lie. An exception declaration is a close analogue of a code comment because it talks about code instead of being code. As for which exceptions should be declared, it is usually redundant to declare such general exceptions as NullPointerExecption or IllegalArgumentException because there is little point in ever catching them.

But @MarkoTopolnik, the declaration in the API is as close to the source as possible, and also visible directly in the IDE. I would not refute it like this. Maybe I'd even go further and say that the best place is actually the declaration and not the implementation, since the latter can change more easily while the declaration is (supposedly) compatible. Not sure if I'm interpreting too much into your statement :)

Regarding your "Edit" section, know that politicians love to redefine time zones, offsets, Daylight Saving Time (DST), etc. So never go too far into the future with UTC values. If you mean dental hygiene appointments made far in advance, ex. “3 PM on December 5th, 2017 later this year”, then you may indeed want to use a LocalDateTime to store that fact. The intent there is 3 PM however politicians may have redefined that moment by then. For a schedule you might temporarily apply time zone to to the potential LocalDateTime to generate an actual moment as a ZonedDateTime/Instant.

in the JPanel class I have created, called Display2. - Display2 is a JPanel which is already visible by default. That statement is not needed anywhere in the class. The fact that you have commented out code in this class dealing with menus also indicates a problem with the structure of your classes. The menus should be created when you create the frame. In addition to the link I proved in my comment you should be reading the Swing tutiroal on Custom Painting for painting examples with better structured code.

In Display2, you call setVisible() first, then initialize the class. You need to do that in the opposite order. Init all the components first, then call setVisible(). Otherwise there's no work for the initial drawing to do, and adding a bunch of components later likely don't get drawn. Also I'm seconding the request for a complete example. You're likely just not calling repaint() (or setVisible()) properly, so it'll have something to do with the flow of the code when you start up. We can't see what's going on based on what you posted.

Why are you creating a new instance of the Display2 class? The panel should be added to the frame when the frame is constructed. Then you change the properties of the Display2 class when you want to change the painting. I would guess the problem is the size of the panel is (0, 0) when it is created so there is nothing to paint. See the DrawOnComponent example from Custom Painting Approaches for an example of how to do the painting.

First and foremost - repaint makes no guarantee that a component will be repainted or when it might be repainted. The request is passed onto the RepaintManager which makes determinations about what and when a paint pass should occur. There are many decisions to be made and many reasons why a component might not be repainted upon request. Consider providing a minimal reproducible example which demonstrates you issue as out-of-context code is just guess work which basically comes down to "I guess you're doing something wrong"

Polymorphism is a broader concept than subclassing/overriding. Overloading, for example, also is a form of Polymorphism. Generics too.

Subclassing can be augmentation w/o overrides, e.g., a base class provides common functionality, and subclasses extend/use that functionality without replacing it. This isn't as unusual as the preceding comments imply (for better or worse). (Whether or not subclassing is the best approach, then, is a separate conversation, e.g., composition may make more sense.)

the job will create the necessary metadata tables automatically: that's not correct, Spring Batch does not create tables automatically, it is up to you to do it manually or tell Spring boot to do it for you (as in your case). You need to make sure your liquibase script runs before the job so that Spring Batch can find the tables and report its meta-data.

One way of combining characters into emojis is using the zero-width-joiner codepoint (ZWJ/ U+200D). So one way to get the count of visible characters is to go over all unicode codepoints and whenever you encounter the ZWJ, you substract two (for the ZWJ and for the next character which is merged into the previous character). However there are more ways to compose emojis (and unicode characters) so your best bet is to wait for emoji4j to update or to do it yourself.

The general reality of regex's is that running separate ones means they are disconnected and are not related to each other in space-time. Its like a Picasso vs a da Vinci. One does not flow from the other, there is a discontinuity, it's the kind of logic that software engineers working for SpaceX use.. why they all crash. Using the \G anchor insures the literal text exists before the other variables are matched. Its called the double-brace (anti-)pattern. It creates an anonymous class and then has an initializer-block in it (which is executed during its construction). new Foo(){...} for the anonymous class and {...} inside it for an intializer block.
It's an anonymous subclass with an instance initializer block. It's a bad idea and it's often called Double Brace initialization because it's often formatted as new Something() {{ doThing }}.

Unless you are writing a high performance server or high traffic client (you aren't), you don't need to keep an open database connection, you can just open one when you need data, then shut it. If you really do want to reuse connections, then use a connection pool (e.g. hikari). You could develop your own method for pooling or reusing connections, but I wouldn't advise it. A database connection is only a connection, it is not like a stateful web session with session data. Data is stored in your app or the database, it is not in the connection.
Which Easter?  In the Western world, Easter in 2023 was April 9th.  In the Orthodox world, April 16th.

The question is a bit broad for this forum, but generally you should create a class which encapsulates all the database code. That class can keep a single connection which it opens in the constructor and provides a close() method to close it. Create an instance of that class in your Application subclass start() or init() method, and call it’s close() method from the stop() method. Then just pass that instance to the “scenes” (or controllers if you are using FXML) that need it.
Don’t use singletons. That is an anti-pattern.

If your issue is solely with the delete not working, that you are trying to delete something and seeing an issue because you want it gone in the end - you are, as the error suggest, passing in an entity that you've marked to delete to the save/merge operation. Look at your model again, you've got references between entities marked as cascade merge. So if they aren't null when one of those entities is saved, the save is likely cascading to the entity you want to delete, causing it to undo the delete. Clear and manage your references and the problem will go away.

You shouldn't try this, as JPA does caching by the entity ID - delete then persist is pretty much just an undo operation internally so I don't know why you'd want delete then insert statements. That said, your issue is not likely with the delete then persist, but with your transactional context; the same issue you have in your other question. Put another way, are any changes you make committed and visible through your DB client? @Transactional is a Spring thing, so you'd have to look at the contracts and how your methods chain together to understand why this might not work the way you want

@tchrist: it recommends against using a BOM when dealing with software and protocols that excepts ASCII-only chars. If the OP knows that the Windows software he's using will use the BOM to detect that the file is actually encoded in UTF-8 (we don't care about the fact that it ain't a BOM, we care about the fact that it can allow some software to detect that the encoding is UTF-8). Also note that if you had a BOM to UTF-8 and some software fail, then these software are broken, because a BOM at the beginning of an UTF-8 is perfectly valid.
Yes, that’s right. The Unicode standard recommends against using a so-called BOM (it isn’t really) with UTF-8.
Yes, we are trying to the view the csv in Windows, but the generated csv still shows garbled character for german characters. Is this the right way to set the BOM?

Just in case you haven't come across this before, note that the Unicode standard does not require or recommend using a BOM with UTF-8. It isn't illegal, either, but shouldn't be used indiscriminately. See here for the details, including some guidelines on when and where to use it. If you are trying to view the csv file in Windows, this is probably a valid use of the BOM.

no security manager: RMI class loader disabled is not an exception. It is part of the error message printed by a ClassNotFoundException in an RMI context. The problem you are facing doesn't necessarily have anything to do with remote class loading, unless you have designed it into your application, in which case you should know about it. More likely you just haven't deployed some required class. Without the actual exception and the actual stack trace it is impossible to comment further.

And please bring your error handling into the 21st century. Add mysqli_report(MYSQLI_REPORT_ERROR | MYSQLI_REPORT_STRICT); before your mysqli_connect() (or new mysqli()) command, and this will ensure that errors with your SQL queries are reported correctly to PHP automatically. That way you don't need to clutter your script with repetitive code to keep checking errors after every mysqli command. And you should never be echoing error data deliberately - it can easily reveal sensitive info to attackers by accident.
Also, please don't store passwords in plain text - that is another security risk. Learn about password hashing instead. See also How to use PHP's password_hash to hash and verify passwords
P.S. It's not very secure to send a password in a URL GET parameter...it can easily by logged by webservers, routers etc. Better to send a POST request with the data in the body, and use HTTPS.

@Elist yes, I really do see what you're saying... it's just that I'm not really sure this is part of the "testing" phase of a project in the sense of TDD. You seem to think that this will help "ship a hotfix ASAP"... but when are planning to run these 3rd party input tests?  I suggest that if this 3rd party source is critical you'd want your app to be testing this 3rd party source regularly: every day/hour/whatever.  Perhaps even set up a special service to do this... If it made sense you could use Gradle's Java classes as part of app code, if you like the way it handles task management.

@mikerodent of course the app should behave gracefully on failure, and of course this good behaviour should be tested as part of regression tests and only when your own code changes. But let's agree that the need of the software deployer to be alerted of changes in external (even "random") dependencies and ship a hotfix ASAP can easily be addressed by running tests on unchanged code, tests which results does not have to appear as part of the testing suits of the app, but alert the product team in some other way. Inputs from an external source are sometimes an essential part of functionality.

@Elist I understand what you're saying... but 2 points: first, if your app has to cater for third party inputs changing, this versatility (including the ability to "hang up the phone" gracefully and cleanly and in a non-puzzling way during a run) needs to be part of your app code, not your testing code, and you have to anticipate in your app this input becoming incomprehensible. A secondary point is that the testing suites for your app shouldn't show fails or passes which result from "random" outside input: your tests should only be to tell you one thing: is your app a functional thing?

@mikerodent consider testing your code against a 3rd party online service. You would want to monitor possible changes in the service API to be able to respond with deployed fixes ASAP. Isn't CI tests a good way of doing that? Using a mock will only tell you your own code doesn't have regressions, but the dependencies still might have changes. using the real service would indicate that your product can actually perform the expected operations in the current environment.

Sorry to be nit-picky, but I don't really think this is the correct way of thinking about this: if you have variable 3-party inputs isn't the correct way of dealing with this to mock these inputs in some way?  Testing should actually be about testing the code you're writing.  Aren't you in fairly obvious danger of getting false-positives if you're relying on 3-party input to be unacceptable?  Shouldn't the strategy be to cater for problem input as part of your app code?

You can get away with a filter that understands when a request is for static content and responds itself; you will have to reproduce some (or all?) of the functionality of the static resource servlet. If you only want to serve the swagger.yaml, then you may create a JAX-RS service that responds to this URL by loading e.g the file from the classpath and sets the right headers.

Problem is that the servlet container has a default servlet that handles the static content. When you define a servlet with the same mapping i.e. /*, this will shadow the static content servlet. When the Resteasy servlet invoked, if it can't find the requested static content, it will not fallback to the default servlet. I know Jersey has a configuration property to set, where it handle the static content itself, but I don't know about Resteasy. I checked, but you can check again

Talking of Instant, the docs say that the ISO_INSTANT formatter is for Instant objects, which seems to imply that it doesn’t work for parsing into ZonedDateTime. It’s logical: for a ZonedDateTime you would need a date, a time of day and a time zone such as Africa/Cairo or Etc/UTC. An instant does not suffice.

Just use ZonedDateTime.parse("2011-12-03T10:15:30Z") and do not specify any formatter. However ZonedDateTime doesn’t seem to be the correct class to use for that string. Consider using Instantinstead.

The goal of reusing the same client port instantly cannot safely be met. It would violate a key part of TCP security. NB The SO_LINGERmechanism has nothing to do with the TIME_WAIT state. It provides a timeout on close() while there is still outbound data in flight. All that precedes the TIME_WAIT state, which starts after the socket is closed. It has no bearing on 'port in use' whatsoever. Setting it to (true, 0) as you have causes the connection to be reset on close, which loses all the data in flight. You don't want that. It can upset the peer as well.

You use the mechanism PKCS11Constants.CKM_SHA256_RSA_PKCS. But that mechanism does calculate the hash of the data, wrap it in a DigestInfo structure, apply PKCS#1 1.5 padding, and encrypt. As far as I understand your code, though, you already have calculated the hash and wrapped it in a DigestInfo structure and only want PKCS#1 1.5 padding and encryption to be applied. Thus, you may want to use the mechanism PKCS11Constants.CKM_RSA_PKCS instead.

@matt Java 8 does not necessarily annotate hotspot intrinsic methods. Those methods can replace a pure java method. (And if you change one, but not the other...). Anyway, Math.pow() is a hotspot intrinsic since java 6.

@Holger maybe a misunderstanding: StrictMath produces the same result across jdks, but not the same result like the Math counterpart. Example:  JVM VERSION: 17.0.6 Input number: 1.0 Math result (java.lang.Math.exp):  -> 2.718281828459045 StrictMath result (java.lang.StrictMath.exp):  -> 2.7182818284590455

@Holger 1.0 gives different results for Math and StrictMath, that means java 21 StrictMath cannot be used for java 8 Math. The 0.003978202863827189 example gives a different result for java 17 Math and java 8 Math.

@MarkRotteveel yes that's also my best guess... and yes, java.lang.Math delegates to java.lang.StrictMath, BUT because of intrinsic functions the jvm can do something different during runtime to improve performance (e.g. call native code) see also this list: chriswhocodes.com/hotspot_intrinsics_openjdk8.html

@matt yes, it is a good idea to use StrictMath in the future or any other math library which ensures consistency across versions and platforms.  For now it doesn't solve the problem because StrictMath doesn't deliver the same results like java 8 Math. Check with exp function and number 1.0d

I'm going to go out on a limb and guess that in Java 11 (or earlier) they made some changes which affected the non-strict floating point operations, and instead of changing it back (it likely still complied with the spec), they decided to ditch that non-strict behaviour entirely through JEP-306, so they now only have behaviour that complies with the IEEE-754 standard.
You should be able to "Any ideas how the same math behaviour can be achieved?" You should be able to use StrictMath instead of Math and get the same results for both jdks.

@SharonBenAsher Given the shortcuts used can result in slightly different values, and if you then consider compound error, the results between the old default behaviour and the strict behaviour can result in larger deviations.

@SharonBenAsher Older Java version used shortcuts/different calculations (at least on x86) for floating point operations for historic reasons (e.g. it was slower to use strictly conforming calculations on some hardware), and only formally complied with the IEEE-754 standard if you tagged the variables with the strictfp keyword. This changed in Java 17 with JEP-306, the default behaviour is now the same as the strictfp behaviour.

You're modifying the values stored in freqMap and using them to do comparisons in your PriorityQueue comparator. Not an answer to the question, but for general stream advice: This may not be the best example, because with Streams it makes more sense to do something like List<Integer> newList = list.stream().filter(...).collect(...); then use the result of the stream (newList) from there on. Streams are much easier to grasp if you think about them as functions that return a result (whether it is modified or created new) that you may further operate on, not the original source. Then you shouldn't (in most cases) have to worry about implementation details like this.

As others have said, when reading (large) files into buffers, direct buffers should be better, as heap buffers do not have an absolute address so the may need to be cached somewhere else first. Using direct buffers may additionally have the benefit of allowing a completely native IO operation (potentially even asynchronous) without the vm having to do anything.

@veer That's the "by-the-book" explanation. I am looking more for a rule. Eventually you have to read the direct buffer into Java space, so the kernel boundary will have to be crossed sooner or later.

Direct buffers try to allocate the memory contiguously rather than allocating Java arrays locally. You want to do this because it reduces the amount of work to be done during I/O since a native buffer is ready as-is to be passed to the kernel, while using non-native buffers requires an additional pass.

Always assume that any method which returns an array or collection will return an empty array/collection rather than null.  Why?  Because treating null as equivalent to an empty array or collection is a horrible design.  No one should ever, under any circumstances, treat null as equivalent to an empty array or collection.  null is a poison value that should never be used for any structured type.

@shmosel is correct.  avoid having calculated fields like a user sum of scores where possible, but sometimes it is necessary to achieve adequate performance; very much depends on what you are doing.  for instance, if you repeatedly need a fast, real time list of the 10 users with the top total score across all your users, that might weigh towards storing a sum. Since you're already retrieving the count as value it should be map.put(String.valueOf(A.charAt(i)), value+1);. However, also note that map.get(A.charAt(i)) uses the character to lookup the value which doesn't matrch because you're converting the characters to strings when putting them into the map. So either always use a string or change the map key to Character.

@Turing85 yes, if you call left() without ensuring that isLeft() is true you will get a ClassCastException. That is why that code is there to catch that instead of silently failing because of erasure. If you didn't care about that you wouldn't need to pass in the Class objects at all.

@ArtB from the documentation of Class#cast(Object o): "Throws: ClassCastException - if the object is not null and is not assignable to the type T." In other words: if A and B are not related, you will get an ClassCastException.
@Turing85 They are not expected to be related, you know which method is safe to call by checking the isLeft() method before calling left()

Perhaps if you try to implement what you want using anonymous classes first, then you can at least get everything working like you want. Then convert the anonymous classes to lambda expressions (your IDE might provide an "action" that does such a conversion for you).

It's important you realize that a lambda expression is essentially just "syntactic sugar" (i.e., shorthand) for defining an implementation of a functional interface, which an interface with a single abstract method (SAM). In this case, you're trying to implement GridComponent whose SAM is getEncoding(). That means the lambda expression will have no parameters and must return a String. But the lambda you have in the question is defining a single parameter c and trying to return GridComponent. See the problem?

Sonar is for scanning Java source code. Java source code can't contain preprocessor conditions. Or put differently: if your source file contains preprocessor statements, then it isn't Java source code. Using preprocessors is exceedingly rare in the Java world, so you'll be hard-pressed to find many tools that support it (and most tools that handle Java source code won't consider it a bug if they don't support it).
Also, never write an empty catch block. In this case, it should contain throw new RuntimeException(e);. (Do you really want your program to continue running if the proper fonts couldn’t be loaded?)

Your lambda c -> { ... } is implementing the functional interface GridComponent. i.e. c -> { ... } is an implementation of String getEncoding(). So it should take nothing and return a string. The compiler is complaining that it doesn't know what c is. Your actual outer function is more like a Function<Character, GridComponent>. That itself is not a GridComponent; it's something that can give you a GridComponent if you give it a character first.

Your listener is invoked when the user changes the selection. That's why getting the selected item in the listener worked (though you don't handle the case where the user clears the selection). But you could have used other approaches (e.g., maybe you want the user to press a button to display the details, thus you would put the get-selected-item code in the button's on-action handler). Also, note that, in your code, todoListView.getSelectionModel().getSelectedItem() is returning the same object that newValue references (i.e., you could just do todoDetails.setText(newValue.getDetails()))

Ultimately, it's a question of when you want the code to be invoked. If you try to get the selected item directly inside the initialize method, then you're very likely to get null as a result. The initialize method is invoked during the process of loading the FXML file, after the FXML-injected fields have been injected, but before loading has complete (basically, it's the last thing that happens). But that also means it's highly unlikely your ListView has been added to a Scene yet, let alone being displayed. The user could not have selected an item before the list is displayed.

There could be different causes for this. The first is because this App could OBSERVES folder changes and store them in a Database. FileObservers, however, works with Permissions so if you App don't have right Permissions that folder cannot be observed. On newer Android 10/11+ a non-system-App cannot read/write/observe folders that it don't owns. The only workaroud is to Target a lower SDK (< 29) but it cannot be uploaded in the Store starting from few months ago. Please read documentation for FileObserver and Android 10+ to know if you can do what you try to achieve.

Perhaps the piece you're missing is what's called reflection. Reflection can be used to instantiate and invoke code unknown at compile-time. Spring uses reflection, and other tools, to do what it does. Some of those other tools may or may not include compile-time and/or run-time annotation processing, instrumentation, proxies, run-time generation of classes, and so on. But all this code is still executed by the JVM; Spring is not "becoming" the JVM in any way.

Besides the starting and ending grid squares, only the border grid squares matter, right (because your direction is otherwise completely fixed by what direction you were traveling from the last time you were on a border square)? With this, only O(R + C) nodes are needed that correspond to the border squares, where R and C are the number of rows and columns of the grid, respectively. Then, as mentioned previously, Dijkstra's Algorithm is appropriate for this problem, because the edges (the connections between nodes) are weighted (different distances) and positive.

in your algo the purpose of boolean[][] visited array is to prevent infinite loops within single path, however, since that array is global, writing to it prevents your algo from considering other paths - you need at least set visited[i][j] to true after for loop, moreover you nowhere pay attention to direction in which you have seen the cell, so, boolean[][] visited is not a good structure there, boolean[M][N][4] visited seems to be more suitable. btw, after fixing that you will get TLE error

There's nothing particularly special about Spring; it's complicated, but not particularly special. You call the framework's entry point and that causes code to execute, like normal.  It's just that said code does stuff like scan the class-path for annotations, set up network connections, set up the handling of incoming connections, initialize "sub" frameworks (e.g., JPA) as needed, instantiate objects "for you" as needed, and so on. But that's all just Java code, same as you write in your programs.
The Spring container is executed like any other Java code: as Java code, by the JVM.
The Spring framework, like all Java code (ignoring things like Android and GraalVM native images), is executed by the JVM. So, no, the JVM does not "hand over" execution to Spring.

Rajni, Java is a very old programming language and ever evolving. This is good so, but it also means that on the internet you find very old code examples that are far from the best to use with newer Java versions. In general don’t accept code written for anything older than Java 8 (AKA 1.8; out 2014), and if you can find still newer, prefer it. Since Java 1.7 you may also prefer using Path, Files and FileTime from Java NIO over the old File class., They have more consistent support for creation and modified dates.

@dave_thompson_085 The OP is starting with a file with multiple PEM-formatted X509 certificates - there's absolutely no need to convert that to a PKCS12 file with OpenSSL and then drag Bouncy Castle in to read that PKCS12 file. Read the file into a Java PKCS12 keystore in Java, then write the PKCS12 keystore to a file.

@AndrewHenle: in code you don't need to split a PEM sequence, instead use CertificateFactory.generateCertificates (with s) and loop over the result. But the Bouncy part of my comment was specifically about using an openssl-created pkcs12, as in the Q, which does not use PEM or CertificateFactory at all.

Note that "error: cannot find symbol" is just a small part of the complete error message. The complete error message contains information about which source file contains the error, at which line in the source file it occurs and what symbol the compiler doesn't find. All this information is there to help you find the problem.

@dave_thompson_085 No need to drag Bouncy Castle into the solution. Just break the input file into separate X509 PEM Strings, use an X509 certificate factory to create X509 objects from the strings, and load the X509s into a Java KeyStore object.

Your hex value 7573746f726530313233343536373839 is the characters ustore0123456789 not 0123456789 plus nulls, and as @Artjom says your Java does AES-128 ECB mode (and PKCS#5 padding which OpenSSL also does). Further, the echo command (in bash a builtin) adds a newline to the data but your Java doesn't, and openssl enc -a encodes the result in base64 not hex. Fixing these: echo -n lun01 |openssl aes-128-ecb -K 30313233343536373839000000000000 |od -tx1 gives 0000000 d2 30 b2 16 e9 d6 59 64 ab d4 09 2f 5c 45 5a 21 matching your Java result.

"Saving a child first doesn't help either, only exception is different" - Or maybe try to persist child, persist parent, add child to parent, set child's parent, merge child, merge parent. Somewhat clumsy, even if it works.

I think this is only partially true. As long as you are using a single persistence context and don't detach the persistent entities from it the objects are "attached" to it. This means that the context will be able (through proxy objects or instrumentation) to determine exactly which property of which of the persistent object(s) has changed since the last sync with the DB and persist/merge only those, without an additional round-trip to the DB. This basically means that the persistence provider already manages and uses an internal flag for you to note which objects are "dirty" w.r.t. the DB.

That all because I don't have consistent sync with database, let's say my entities can change in time, and if I have parent with 1000 children, without cascade I simply check if child was changed (it has an extra boolean attribute for that) and save/merge only it. If I used cascade It would check every 1000 children by requesting database (and I'm not talking about other relations there), and that is a LOT of database requests!

Why would you add children to a parent before persisting the parent, but not wanting to persist them too? - How about first persisting the parent and then, working with the persistent parent entity, add children as needed? When you're done, you merge() the new parent's state, including the children, into the DB.

I need to save parent without saving childs, that is why no cascade is needed. Transient is not a solution in my case, I still want childs to be eagerly loaded on parent load. So without cascade, Spring JPA (or hibernate persistence provider, not sure which one is responsible) is checking every child's persistence. What is the point of this check if I will not save them anyway (or will save later)?

I don't know native2ascii uses which unicode implementation. But it does not matter, the unicode implementation is compatible with ISO-8859-1. Then Properties class can decode properly with ISO-8859-1.

As Thilo suggested, the -encoding option is what the actual encoding of source file. When saving test.properties with "ISO-8859-1" encoding, then iso88591.propertie: key=\u00dc and value via getProperty("key") is correct. 'native2ascii -encoding ISO-8859-1 test.properties iso88591.propertie'
JDK doc: docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/Properties.html. " except the input/output stream is encoded in ISO 8859-1 character encoding"

In UNICODE that character is U+00DC. In UTF-8 encoding, it would be 0xC39C. When that file was read with ISO-8859-1 encoding, it read the UTF-8 encoded character as two ISO-8859-1 encoded characters: 0xC3 0x09c. As Thilo suggested, make the --encoding parameter match the actual encoding of the file.
That -encoding needs to match the actual encoding used in your source file. From the looks of it, that is UTF-8.
